bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: The writer believes Cuba should not be quarantined until yellow fever appears again.

div1.head: Notes on the Stegomyia Mosquito, [19--]
div1.p:
Attention is called to the fact that the stegomyia
is parasitic in its habits and being also of delicate organ-
ism seeks shelter in human habitations where it is exposed
to its enemies of which there are a large number such as
spiders, ants, beetles, house lizards, etc. The stegomyia
is more easily affected by moderately cold weather than its
enemies and becoming torpid becomes anis easy prey to them.
In the winter months this takes place in Cuba. The conten-
tion of the Cuban Government is that between the efforts of
its sanitary department and the beneficial effects of the
climate during the winter months the slate has been cleaned
certainly with regard Havana and its environments and probably
with regard the rest of the Island and that the United States
should withhold action (establishment of quarantine) until yellow
fever again appears in the Island; that withholding quarantine
until a new case appears would beis a moral obligation arising
from the comity of nations in the absence of all treaty
stipulations and the existence of the sanitary convention of
1905 makes such obligation positive and certain.
